title: Thrill-seekers are left hanging upside down on a roller coast due to a sudden power cut in China
text:
A group of thrill-seekers have been rescued unhurt after a theme park in China had a sudden power cut when they were on a roller coast.

Trending footage shows the funfair-goers left hanging upside down in the white-knuckle ride after the train came to an unexpected halt when it was about to plunge.

The stuck tourists had to climb out of their seats on the 196-foot-tall machinery with the help of park workers before walking down via emergency stairs.

No one was injured in the accident which took place on October 1 at Phoenix Happy World in Linyi in eastern China's Shandong Province, according to reports.

A video of the scene went viral this week on Twitter-like Weibo.

The three-minute clip, filmed by a shocked eyewitness, shows multiple riders being stranded in the train which was about to plunge from a high point.

Two riders are seen slowly walking down the stairs on the roller coaster after being freed.

Tourists are stuck in the roller coaster train while hanging upside down (left) before being freed by workers of the theme park in Linyi, eastern China. No one was hurt in the accident

A spokesperson from the wonderland told news outlet The Paper that the park and its surrounding area were hit by a power cut all of sudden that day.

'The machine did not malfunction,' she said.

The spokesperson added that the park's staff rescued the trapped visitors as soon as possible.

'The electricity company did not know the cause of the power cut either. Perhaps there had been an accident somewhere,' she added.

Phoenix Happy World opened in 2016 and is the largest theme park in Linyi, a city of 10 million people.

Its roller coaster, one of its most popular attractions, stands 60 metres (196 feet) in height and extends 1,000 metres (3,280 feet) in length.
description: The stuck tourists had to climb out of their seats while upside down and descended to the ground via emergency stairs. No one was hurt in the accident on October 1 in Linyi, eastern China.
